name: Dhammapada
description: 423 verses of Buddhist wisdom from the Pali canon, translated by F. Max M√ºller. Each verse is a contemplative oracle drawn from the Buddha's teachings on the mind, suffering, liberation, and the path. Organized across 26 chapters (vaggas) covering themes from duality and earnestness to the nature of self and the way of the sage.

attribution.source_name: Dhammapada ‚Äì The Sacred Books of the East, Vol. X
attribution.note: Translation by F. Max M√ºller (1881). Source text from Project Gutenberg eBook #2017. Artwork from Wikimedia Commons public domain collections.

items.name: Verse 1 ‚Äì The Wheel of Pain

sections.Verse: All that we are is the result of what we have thought: it is founded on our thoughts, it is made up of our thoughts. If a man speaks or acts with an evil thought, pain follows him, as the wheel follows the foot of the ox that draws the carriage.
sections.Interpretation: Mind is the forerunner of all action. This verse establishes the central Buddhist teaching of karma as mental causation: unwholesome intention produces suffering as inevitably as a cartwheel tracks the ox. You are not punished for your anger ‚Äî you are punished by your anger. What pattern of thought is pulling your cart today?
sections.Reversed: Blaming external circumstances for inner pain. Refusing to see how your own thinking creates the rut you walk in. The wheel keeps turning because you keep stepping.

questions: What thought pattern is pulling pain behind it in your life right now?
Where are you acting from reactivity rather than awareness?

items.name: Verse 2 ‚Äì The Shadow of Joy

sections.Verse: All that we are is the result of what we have thought: it is founded on our thoughts, it is made up of our thoughts. If a man speaks or acts with a pure thought, happiness follows him, like a shadow that never leaves him.
sections.Interpretation: The twin of verse 1: where impure thought brings suffering, pure thought brings happiness as inseparably as your shadow. This is not moralism but observation ‚Äî wholesome intention naturally produces well-being. Joy is not something you chase; it follows from the quality of your attention.
sections.Reversed: Seeking happiness in possessions, status, or others' approval while neglecting the quality of your own mind. Looking everywhere for the shadow except at the body casting it.

questions: When has acting from genuine goodness brought you unexpected joy?
What would it feel like to stop chasing happiness and let it follow you?

items.name: Verse 3 ‚Äì The Grudge That Grows

sections.Verse: "He abused me, he beat me, he defeated me, he robbed me," ‚Äî in those who harbour such thoughts hatred will never cease.
sections.Interpretation: The mind that rehearses grievances becomes a prison of its own making. Each replay of the injury freshens the wound and feeds the hatred. The Buddha does not say the harm was not real ‚Äî he says the holding is the second arrow. The story you keep telling yourself is now hurting you more than the original event.
sections.Reversed: Identifying so completely with victimhood that it becomes your identity. The grudge has become more familiar than freedom. You are now the jailer and the jailed.

questions: What old injury are you still replaying?
Is the story you keep telling yourself still serving you, or has it become its own form of harm?

items.name: Verse 4 ‚Äì Releasing the Story

sections.Verse: "He abused me, he beat me, he defeated me, he robbed me," ‚Äî in those who do not harbour such thoughts hatred will cease.
sections.Interpretation: The twin release: the same events, the same words, but a different relationship to them. Not harbouring does not mean denying or condoning ‚Äî it means refusing to let the past colonize the present. When you stop feeding the fire of resentment, it goes out on its own. This is not forgiveness as performance ‚Äî it is forgiveness as freedom.
sections.Reversed: Spiritual bypassing ‚Äî pretending not to be hurt rather than genuinely releasing. Suppressing rather than transmuting. True release requires first acknowledging the wound.

questions: What would your life look like if you truly stopped carrying this?
Can you distinguish between suppressing pain and genuinely releasing it?

items.name: Verse 5 ‚Äì The Old Rule

sections.Verse: For hatred does not cease by hatred at any time: hatred ceases by love, this is an old rule.
sections.Interpretation: Perhaps the most quoted verse of the Dhammapada. Hatred is a fire ‚Äî pouring more hatred on it only makes it burn higher. Only the water of love (metta, loving-kindness) extinguishes it. This is not naive idealism but practical psychology: meeting aggression with aggression escalates; meeting it with compassion disarms. The Buddha calls this 'an old rule' ‚Äî eternal, discovered anew in every generation.
sections.Reversed: Using 'love conquers all' as a platitude to avoid setting boundaries. Love without wisdom becomes enabling. The old rule requires courage, not passivity.

questions: Where in your life are you fighting fire with fire?
What would it look like to respond to hostility with genuine compassion ‚Äî not weakness, but strength?

items.name: Verse 6 ‚Äì The End That Quiets

sections.Verse: The world does not know that we must all come to an end here; ‚Äî but those who know it, their quarrels cease at once.
sections.Interpretation: Awareness of death is the great peacemaker. When you truly remember that you and everyone around you will die, petty disputes dissolve. This is not morbid ‚Äî it is the deepest sanity. The monks who meditate in charnel grounds are not practicing pessimism; they are practicing perspective. What quarrel can survive the knowledge of impermanence?
sections.Reversed: Using mortality as an excuse for nihilism or recklessness ‚Äî 'nothing matters anyway.' The Buddha's point is the opposite: because time is short, don't waste it on conflict.

questions: If you knew you had one year to live, which of your current conflicts would you drop instantly?
How would remembering death change the argument you are in right now?

items.name: Verse 7 ‚Äì The Weak Tree

sections.Verse: He who lives looking for pleasures only, his senses uncontrolled, immoderate in his food, idle, and weak, Mara (the tempter) will certainly overthrow him, as the wind throws down a weak tree.
sections.Interpretation: Mara ‚Äî the Buddhist personification of temptation and distraction ‚Äî needs no great power to topple someone with no roots. A life built entirely on sense pleasure has no anchor when the storms come. The weak tree is not evil; it is simply ungrounded. Without discipline, without purpose beyond the next pleasure, you become vulnerable to every passing wind.
sections.Reversed: Excessive asceticism or guilt about enjoying life. The Buddha himself rejected extreme self-denial. The Middle Way includes pleasure ‚Äî but not slavery to it.

questions: Where are you living on autopilot, driven by the next hit of comfort or stimulation?
What wind would it take to knock you over right now?

items.name: Verse 8 ‚Äì The Rocky Mountain

sections.Verse: He who lives without looking for pleasures, his senses well controlled, moderate in his food, faithful and strong, him Mara will certainly not overthrow, any more than the wind throws down a rocky mountain.
sections.Interpretation: The twin of verse 7: same wind, different foundation. The person rooted in self-mastery ‚Äî senses controlled, needs moderate, purpose clear ‚Äî stands immovable. This is not rigidity but stability. A mountain does not fight the wind; it simply does not move. Strength here is not aggression but groundedness, the quiet power of someone who knows who they are.
sections.Reversed: Mistaking stubbornness for strength. Being so rigid that you cannot bend, adapt, or receive. A mountain that cannot feel the wind is a statue, not a sage.

questions: What gives you your foundation ‚Äî the thing that keeps you standing when everything shakes?
Is your stability rooted in genuine self-knowledge, or in fear of change?

items.name: Verse 9 ‚Äì The Stained Robe

sections.Verse: He who wishes to put on the yellow dress without having cleansed himself from sin, who disregards temperance and truth, is unworthy of the yellow dress.
sections.Interpretation: The yellow (saffron) robe symbolizes the monastic path, but the teaching is universal: outer signs of virtue without inner transformation are a costume, not a commitment. Wearing the robes of wisdom while living in delusion is the deepest hypocrisy. The verse asks: are you living your values, or just performing them?
sections.Reversed: Judging others' spiritual credentials while ignoring your own inconsistencies. Every tradition has gatekeepers who police appearances rather than cultivating depth.

questions: Where are you wearing the costume of transformation without doing the inner work?
What gap exists between what you profess and how you actually live?

items.name: Verse 10 ‚Äì The Worthy Robe

sections.Verse: But he who has cleansed himself from sin, is well grounded in all virtues, and regards also temperance and truth, he is indeed worthy of the yellow dress.
sections.Interpretation: The twin completion: when inner reality matches outer expression, the robe becomes sacred. Worthiness is not a title bestowed by others but a state of alignment between intention and action. The person who has done the work ‚Äî cleansed, grounded, temperate, truthful ‚Äî wears their commitments as naturally as their skin.
sections.Reversed: Imposter syndrome ‚Äî having done genuine work but feeling perpetually unworthy. Sometimes the cleansing is complete and you are allowed to own it.

questions: Where in your life does your inner reality match your outer expression?
Have you done enough work to trust yourself, and if so, can you own that?

items.name: Verse 11 ‚Äì Truth in Untruth

sections.Verse: They who imagine truth in untruth, and see untruth in truth, never arrive at truth, but follow vain desires.
sections.Interpretation: Delusion is not simply ignorance ‚Äî it is active misperception, seeing what is not there and missing what is. When you mistake comfort for truth, or dismiss uncomfortable truths as false, you build your life on sand. 'Vain desires' are not just material wants; they include the desire for reality to be other than it is. Clear seeing begins with the willingness to be wrong.
sections.Reversed: Paralysis from radical skepticism ‚Äî doubting everything until nothing is trustworthy. The verse warns against misperception, not against trust itself.

questions: What comfortable belief might you be mistaking for truth?
Where are you refusing to see something because it would require you to change?

items.name: Verse 12 ‚Äì Truth in Truth

sections.Verse: They who know truth in truth, and untruth in untruth, arrive at truth, and follow true desires.
sections.Interpretation: Clear seeing: recognizing things as they actually are. This is prajna ‚Äî wisdom that cuts through confusion. When you can distinguish the real from the fabricated, your desires naturally align with reality. 'True desires' are not desires you suppress but desires that arise from seeing clearly. Right understanding leads to right aspiration. You want what is actually good for you.
sections.Reversed: Weaponizing 'truth-telling' ‚Äî using bluntness as cruelty. Knowing the truth is not the same as knowing when and how to speak it.

questions: What do you know to be true that you have been avoiding acting on?
If you saw your situation with perfect clarity, what would you do differently?

items.name: Verse 13 ‚Äì The Leaking Roof

sections.Verse: As rain breaks through an ill-thatched house, passion will break through an unreflecting mind.
sections.Interpretation: The mind without mindfulness is an open invitation to every passing craving, fear, and obsession. 'Passion' here (raga) means not just lust but any overwhelming emotion that floods unchecked through consciousness. The thatching is not suppression but awareness ‚Äî the careful, deliberate work of watching your own mind. Without that roof, every storm drenches you.
sections.Reversed: Over-thatching: building so many defenses and walls that nothing gets through ‚Äî not even genuine feeling, connection, or inspiration. A sealed house is also a prison.

questions: Where is your mental roof leaking ‚Äî what overwhelms you because you haven't attended to it?
What practice could you strengthen that would protect your peace of mind?

items.name: Verse 14 ‚Äì The Sheltering Mind

sections.Verse: As rain does not break through a well-thatched house, passion will not break through a well-reflecting mind.
sections.Interpretation: The reflective mind ‚Äî one trained in meditation and self-awareness ‚Äî does not prevent rain from falling. Cravings, fears, and provocations still arise. But they find no way in. The well-thatched house still hears the storm; it simply stays dry inside. This is equanimity: not the absence of difficulty but the presence of an unshakable inner shelter you have built through practice.
sections.Reversed: Confusing detachment with dissociation. A well-thatched roof lets you hear the rain. If you feel nothing at all, you may have sealed yourself off rather than found peace.

questions: What storms are you currently weathering well because of work you have done on yourself?
How did you build the shelter you have ‚Äî and where does it still need reinforcement?

items.name: Verse 15 ‚Äì Mourning in Both Worlds

sections.Verse: The evil-doer mourns in this world, and he mourns in the next; he mourns in both. He mourns and suffers when he sees the evil of his own work.
sections.Interpretation: This is not divine punishment but natural consequence. The person who acts harmfully suffers twice: once from the external results, and once from the internal recognition of what they have done. Conscience is not optional ‚Äî even the most hardened heart eventually confronts its own deeds. 'The next world' can be read literally or as the future self who inherits today's choices.
sections.Reversed: Excessive guilt that becomes self-punishment rather than motivation to change. Mourning is meant to be a wake-up call, not a life sentence.

questions: What past action still causes you grief when you remember it?
Is your remorse motivating change, or has it become a form of self-punishment?

items.name: Verse 16 ‚Äì Delight in Both Worlds

sections.Verse: The virtuous man delights in this world, and he delights in the next; he delights in both. He delights and rejoices, when he sees the purity of his own work.
sections.Interpretation: The mirror twin of verse 15: virtue brings its own reward, not as cosmic payment but as natural joy. When you look back at your actions and see integrity, the feeling is not pride but a quiet delight ‚Äî muditƒÅ, sympathetic joy extended toward yourself. You can rest in the knowledge that your choices have been wholesome. This is the deepest form of self-respect.
sections.Reversed: Self-righteousness disguised as virtue. Delighting in your own purity while looking down on others is not the joy the Buddha describes ‚Äî it is spiritual vanity.

questions: What actions can you look back on with genuine, quiet pride?
Are you allowing yourself to feel the natural joy of having lived well?

items.name: Verse 17 ‚Äì The Evil Path Deepens

sections.Verse: The evil-doer suffers in this world, and he suffers in the next; he suffers in both. He suffers when he thinks of the evil he has done; he suffers more when going on the evil path.
sections.Interpretation: A deepening of verse 15: not only does the wrongdoer suffer from past misdeeds, but continuing on the same path intensifies the suffering. This is the compounding nature of harmful habits ‚Äî each repetition makes the next easier and the consequences heavier. The verb 'going on' is crucial: it is the continuation, not just the past act, that compounds the pain.
sections.Reversed: Fatalism ‚Äî believing that because you have done harm, you are now 'on the evil path' and cannot leave it. Every moment offers a new choice. The path only deepens if you keep walking it.

questions: Where are you continuing a pattern you already know causes suffering?
What would it take to step off a path you are on, even mid-stride?

items.name: Verse 18 ‚Äì The Good Path Brightens

sections.Verse: The virtuous man is happy in this world, and he is happy in the next; he is happy in both. He is happy when he thinks of the good he has done; he is still more happy when going on the good path.
sections.Interpretation: The positive mirror: virtue compounds just as vice does, but toward joy instead of suffering. Each wholesome act makes the next more natural, and the cumulative effect is a deepening happiness. 'Still more happy when going on the good path' ‚Äî the direction matters more than any single act. A life of increasing goodness builds its own momentum, like a river finding its way downhill.
sections.Reversed: Resting on past good deeds while the present goes unattended. The path brightens only while you walk it. Yesterday's virtue does not substitute for today's intention.

questions: In what area of your life is goodness building on itself, gaining natural momentum?
Are you walking the good path today, or remembering a path you walked before?

items.name: Verse 19 ‚Äì The Cowherd

sections.Verse: The thoughtless man, even if he can recite a large portion (of the law), but is not a doer of it, has no share in the priesthood, but is like a cowherd counting the cows of others.
sections.Interpretation: Knowledge without practice is borrowed wealth. You can memorize every sutra, quote every teacher, and understand every doctrine ‚Äî and still be a cowherd counting someone else's cattle. The Dharma is not an intellectual exercise; it is a lived reality. This verse is a warning to scholars, teachers, and spiritual seekers who mistake accumulation of knowledge for transformation.
sections.Reversed: Anti-intellectualism ‚Äî dismissing study and learning as merely 'counting cows.' The Buddha valued both understanding and practice. The problem is not knowledge but knowledge without application.

questions: What teaching do you know deeply but have not yet lived?
Are you studying the path or walking it?

items.name: Verse 20 ‚Äì The Practitioner

sections.Verse: The follower of the law, even if he can recite only a small portion (of the law), but, having forsaken passion and hatred and foolishness, possesses true knowledge and serenity of mind, he, caring for nothing in this world or that to come, has indeed a share in the priesthood.
sections.Interpretation: The chapter's culminating verse and the twin completion of verse 19: a single verse lived is worth more than a thousand recited. The true practitioner may know little scripture but has forsaken the three poisons ‚Äî greed, hatred, and delusion ‚Äî and rests in serenity. 'Caring for nothing' is not nihilism but non-attachment: free from clinging to outcomes in this life or any imagined next.
sections.Reversed: Using 'I don't need to study' as an excuse for ignorance. The verse praises the practitioner who knows even a small portion ‚Äî implying they did engage with the teachings, however briefly.

questions: What single teaching have you truly taken into your bones?
What would it feel like to care deeply about your path but not about the outcome?

items.name: Verse 21 ‚Äì The Deathless Path

sections.Verse: Earnestness is the path of immortality (Nirvana), thoughtlessness the path of death. Those who are in earnest do not die, those who are thoughtless are as if dead already.
sections.Interpretation: The chapter's opening salvo: heedfulness (appamada) is the single quality that separates the living from the walking dead. 'Immortality' here is not endless life but Nirvana ‚Äî freedom from the cycle of suffering. The earnest person is truly alive because they are awake; the heedless person is already dead because they sleepwalk through existence. This is not metaphor ‚Äî it is diagnosis.
sections.Reversed: Anxiety disguised as earnestness. Hypervigilance is not the same as wakefulness. True heedfulness is relaxed and alert, not tense and grasping.

questions: In what areas of your life are you sleepwalking?
What would it mean to be fully, earnestly alive today?

items.name: Verse 22 ‚Äì Delight in Waking

sections.Verse: Those who are advanced in earnestness, having understood this clearly, delight in earnestness, and rejoice in the knowledge of the Ariyas (the elect).
sections.Interpretation: Earnestness is not grim duty ‚Äî it becomes its own joy. Those who have practiced long enough discover that wakefulness itself is pleasurable. The 'knowledge of the Ariyas' is not esoteric secret but the lived understanding of those who have walked the path. Delight and rejoicing: the Buddha insists that deep practice is not joyless but deeply satisfying.
sections.Reversed: Spiritual elitism ‚Äî using 'the knowledge of the elect' as a marker of superiority. The joy of practice is open to all, not reserved for an inner circle.

questions: Have you ever experienced the simple joy of being fully present?
When does discipline stop feeling like effort and start feeling like freedom?

items.name: Verse 23 ‚Äì The Highest Happiness

sections.Verse: These wise people, meditative, steady, always possessed of strong powers, attain to Nirvana, the highest happiness.
sections.Interpretation: Three qualities lead to the summit: meditation (jhana), steadiness (unshaken by circumstance), and strong powers (the accumulated strength of consistent practice). Nirvana is not described as escape or void but as 'the highest happiness' ‚Äî sukha at its most complete. The path is not away from joy but toward its deepest form.
sections.Reversed: Postponing happiness until you reach some imagined spiritual finish line. Nirvana is not only a distant goal ‚Äî each moment of genuine meditation and steadiness is a taste of it.

questions: What does 'the highest happiness' mean to you ‚Äî and is it different from ordinary pleasure?
Where in your life do you already experience moments of deep, steady contentment?

items.name: Verse 24 ‚Äì Increasing Glory

sections.Verse: If an earnest person has roused himself, if he is not forgetful, if his deeds are pure, if he acts with consideration, if he restrains himself, and lives according to law, ‚Äî then his glory will increase.
sections.Interpretation: A cascade of conditions, each building on the last: rouse yourself, remember, purify your actions, act thoughtfully, restrain impulse, align with Dharma. 'Glory' (yasa) is not fame but an inner radiance ‚Äî the natural luminosity of a life well-lived. Each condition is achievable; the teaching is practical, not mystical. Start with rousing yourself. The rest follows.
sections.Reversed: Perfectionism ‚Äî believing all six conditions must be met simultaneously or you have failed. The verse is a ladder, not a checklist. Begin with the first rung.

questions: Which rung of this ladder are you on ‚Äî have you roused yourself? Are your deeds pure?
What single quality from this list would most change your life if you strengthened it?

items.name: Verse 25 ‚Äì The Island

sections.Verse: By rousing himself, by earnestness, by restraint and control, the wise man may make for himself an island which no flood can overwhelm.
sections.Interpretation: One of the Dhammapada's most powerful images: you are building an island in the middle of a flood. The flood is samsara ‚Äî the torrent of craving, aversion, and confusion that sweeps away the ungrounded. The island is not isolation but refuge: a place of stability you construct through your own effort. No one can build it for you. No one can take it from you.
sections.Reversed: Using inner stability as a wall against connection. The island is a refuge, not a fortress of solitude. Even the Buddha returned from his island to teach.

questions: What is your island ‚Äî the inner ground that holds when everything floods?
Are you building your refuge, or waiting for someone else to rescue you?

items.name: Verse 26 ‚Äì The Best Jewel

sections.Verse: Fools follow after vanity, men of evil wisdom. The wise man keeps earnestness as his best jewel.
sections.Interpretation: Vanity here is not just pride but anything insubstantial ‚Äî chasing status, accumulating distractions, pursuing what glitters but has no depth. The wise person treats earnestness itself as the most precious thing they own. Not wisdom, not knowledge, not achievement ‚Äî but the quality of attention that makes all of these possible. Guard your earnestness the way you would guard a diamond.
sections.Reversed: Contempt for those you see as 'foolish.' The wise person guards their own jewel; they do not spend their time cataloguing who lacks one.

questions: What are you treating as precious that is actually vanity?
If earnestness were a jewel, how well are you guarding it?

items.name: Verse 27 ‚Äì Ample Joy

sections.Verse: Follow not after vanity, nor after the enjoyment of love and lust! He who is earnest and meditative, obtains ample joy.
sections.Interpretation: The verse does not condemn love but warns against pursuing love and lust as substitutes for inner peace. 'Ample joy' is the key phrase ‚Äî the meditative person does not merely survive without pleasures; they discover a joy more abundant than what pleasure provides. The comparison is not denial versus indulgence but shallow joy versus deep joy.
sections.Reversed: Repressing natural desires out of guilt rather than genuine insight. The Buddha's Middle Way rejects both indulgence and harsh denial.

questions: What shallow pleasure are you pursuing that leaves you emptier afterward?
Have you tasted the 'ample joy' that comes from genuine presence?

items.name: Verse 28 ‚Äì The Mountain View

sections.Verse: When the learned man drives away vanity by earnestness, he, the wise, climbing the terraced heights of wisdom, looks down upon the fools, serene he looks upon the toiling crowd, as one that stands on a mountain looks down upon them that stand upon the plain.
sections.Interpretation: A vivid image of perspective. The wise person does not look down with contempt but with serenity ‚Äî the mountain climber sees the plain with clarity, not superiority. 'Terraced heights' suggests gradual ascent, step by step, not a sudden leap. Each terrace is a level of understanding won through effort. The view from the top is not arrogance but panoramic awareness.
sections.Reversed: Spiritual superiority complex ‚Äî using wisdom as a pedestal. The sage on the mountain who despises the plain has missed the point entirely. Compassion looks down and wants to help, not judge.

questions: From what height are you viewing your current problems ‚Äî too close or with perspective?
When you look at those still struggling, do you feel compassion or judgment?

items.name: Verse 29 ‚Äì The Racer

sections.Verse: Earnest among the thoughtless, awake among the sleepers, the wise man advances like a racer, leaving behind the hack.
sections.Interpretation: The contrast is stark: while others sleep through life, the earnest person moves like a thoroughbred among plodding cart-horses. This is not competition but natural consequence ‚Äî wakefulness has its own velocity. The 'hack' is not a bad person but someone operating far below their potential. The racer does not win by defeating others but by fully using what they have.
sections.Reversed: Impatience with others' pace of growth. The racer's job is to run, not to shame the hack. Each being moves at their own speed.

questions: Are you a racer or a hack in the area of your life that matters most?
Where are you sleepwalking through days that could be fully lived?

items.name: Verse 30 ‚Äì The Rise of Indra

sections.Verse: By earnestness did Maghavan (Indra) rise to the lordship of the gods. People praise earnestness; thoughtlessness is always blamed.
sections.Interpretation: Even the king of the gods earned his position through earnestness, not birthright. The Buddha uses Hindu mythology pragmatically: if diligence can elevate a being to cosmic sovereignty, imagine what it can do for your everyday life. The verse also notes a universal human intuition ‚Äî we praise the diligent and blame the careless. This is not cultural convention but recognition of a natural law.
sections.Reversed: Worshipping achievement and status as the fruit of earnestness while ignoring the quiet, unglamorous diligence of ordinary people. Not every earnest person becomes Indra ‚Äî and that is fine.

questions: What have you achieved solely through sustained effort and attention?
Do you value your own diligence, or only recognize it when it produces visible results?

items.name: Verse 31 ‚Äì Burning the Fetters

sections.Verse: A Bhikshu (mendicant) who delights in earnestness, who looks with fear on thoughtlessness, moves about like fire, burning all his fetters, small or large.
sections.Interpretation: The earnest monk is not extinguished but ablaze ‚Äî moving through the world like a controlled fire that burns only what binds. The 'fetters' (samyojana) are the ten chains that bind beings to samsara: self-illusion, doubt, attachment to rites, sensual desire, ill will, craving for form and formless realms, conceit, restlessness, and ignorance. Fire does not discriminate between large and small ‚Äî it burns everything it touches. So does genuine earnestness.
sections.Reversed: Burning with intensity but without direction ‚Äî passion that destroys rather than liberates. The fire of earnestness has an aim: freedom. Uncontrolled fire is just destruction.

questions: What small fetters are you tolerating that a little earnestness could burn away?
Is your intensity focused on liberation, or just on being busy?

items.name: Verse 32 ‚Äì Close Upon Nirvana

sections.Verse: A Bhikshu (mendicant) who delights in reflection, who looks with fear on thoughtlessness, cannot fall away (from his perfect state) ‚Äî he is close upon Nirvana.
sections.Interpretation: The chapter's closing verse and its gentlest. After the fire of verse 31 comes the stillness of reflection. The one who delights in contemplation 'cannot fall away' ‚Äî this is the promise of irreversibility, that there is a point in practice from which you do not regress. 'Close upon Nirvana' ‚Äî not there yet, but so close that falling back is impossible. The assurance every practitioner needs.
sections.Reversed: Premature certainty ‚Äî believing you cannot fall because you have read about not falling. The verse describes someone who genuinely delights in reflection, not someone who has merely understood the concept.

questions: Have you reached a point in any practice from which you know you will not go back?
What does 'close upon Nirvana' feel like in your experience ‚Äî have you tasted it?
